content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far, far away, there lived a poor prince who possessed a small realm, but it was rich enough to enable him to seek the hand of the Emperor’s daughter in marriage.
Now, this princess was known throughout the land for her beauty, but also for her vanity and pride.
She had a golden ball that she loved more than anything in the world, and she would often sit by her window, tossing it into the air and catching it again, while the courtiers praised her grace.

One day, the prince sent her two of the most precious gifts he could afford: a splendid rose that bloomed only once every five years, its petals shimmering like rubies, and a nightingale whose song was so sweet it could make the saddest heart forget its sorrow.
But the princess, upon receiving them, merely sniffed and said, “What use have I for a rose that wilts?
And as for the bird, it is nothing but a common creature that sings in the trees.
I shall not keep them.”  The prince was heartbroken, but he was also clever.
He disguised himself as a humble swineherd and set off for the Emperor’s palace, where he took up a position tending the royal pigs.
The swineherd’s hut was small and smoky, and the work was hard, but the prince did not mind, for he had a plan.
One day, as the princess strolled through the palace gardens with her ladies-in-waiting, she heard a strange and wonderful sound coming from the swineherd’s hut.
Curious, she crept closer and peeked through the window. There sat the swineherd, tinkering with a small pot.
As he turned a crank, the pot began to play a merry tune, and tiny figures danced upon its lid.
The princess had never seen anything so enchanting. “Oh, swineherd!” she cried. “That pot is marvelous!
What will you take for it?”  The swineherd looked up and said, “I will not sell it for gold or jewels, but I will give it to you if you grant me ten kisses.”  The princess gasped.
“Ten kisses? From a swineherd? Never!”  But her ladies-in-waiting whispered, “What harm is there in it?
The swineherd is young and not unpleasant to look at.” And so, the princess, though reluctant, agreed.
She leaned forward, and the swineherd counted each kiss aloud: “One… two… three…” until he reached ten.
The pot was hers.
The next day, the princess could not resist showing off her new treasure to her father, the Emperor.
She played the pot’s tune again and again, and soon the whole court was laughing and clapping.
But the swineherd had another invention—a rattle that, when shaken, played a hundred different melodies.
The princess had to have it. “What will you take for the rattle?” she asked.
“A hundred kisses from the princess,” the swineherd replied. The princess’s face turned red with indignation. “A hundred kisses?
That is outrageous!”  But her ladies-in-waiting giggled and said, “What does it matter?
The swineherd is only a servant, and no one need know.” So, the princess, though she grumbled, agreed once more.
She stood behind her ladies, who formed a circle around her, shielding her from view as the swineherd counted each kiss: “One… two… three…” until he reached one hundred.
Word of the princess’s strange bargains soon reached the Emperor. He was furious.
“A princess of the royal blood kissing a swineherd?
This is an insult to our house!” He stormed down to the swineherd’s hut, where he found his daughter still giggling over the rattle.
“Enough of this nonsense!” the Emperor roared.
“You are banished from the palace at once!”  The princess wept and pleaded, but the Emperor would not be moved.
She was cast out into the cold night, dressed only in her finest gown, with nothing but the pot and the rattle to her name.
The swineherd, however, followed her. “Why do you follow me?” she sobbed.
“I have nothing left.”  The swineherd removed his disguise and stood before her in his true form—the prince she had scorned.
“You rejected my gifts of beauty and song,” he said, “but you were willing to kiss a swineherd for trinkets.
You are not fit to be my bride.”  The princess fell to her knees, her pride shattered.
“I was foolish and vain,” she cried. “Forgive me!”  But the prince only shook his head.
“It is too late. A true princess values what is real, not what is merely shiny or amusing.
Go now, and learn humility.”  And so, the princess wandered the world, her golden ball lost, her fine gown torn, and her heart heavy with regret.
As for the prince, he returned to his kingdom, where he ruled wisely and well, never again seeking a bride who cared more for baubles than for true worth.
And if the princess ever learned her lesson, no one knows, for she was never seen at the palace again.
